intro: Eupatorium riedelii var. guaranitica, commonly known as the Guaraní feverfew, is a herbaceous perennial native to South America, particularly Brazil. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, fern-like leaves and clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers. The plant is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. It has been traditionally used in herbal medicine for its purported fever-reducing properties. Its botanical features make it a distinctive and ecologically significant species in its native habitat.
